case_title: MUHAMMAD SHARIF vs MEMBER (REVENUE), BOARD OF REVENUE, PUNJAB, LAHORE AND 2 Others
respondant: Member (Revenue), Board of Revenue, Punjab, Lahore
complaint_summary: Muhammad Sharif filed a suit for possession of disputed land through the right of pre-emption, claiming the land was part of his tenancy.
investigation_summary: The Assistant Commissioner Hafizabad decreed the suit in favor of Muhammad Sharif on 26-2-1983. However, the Appellate Authority overturned the decision on 24-6-1984, stating the petitioner cultivated the land as a mortgagee, not as a tenant. A revision petition was dismissed by the Member, Board of Revenue, on 31-10-1985.
judgment_summary: The court dismissed the writ petition, holding that the law granting pre-emption rights to tenants was repugnant to the injunctions of Islam as per the Supreme Court's judgment in P L D 1986 S C 360. The law ceased to have effect on 31-7-1986.
legal_arguments: Reliance on Section 6 of the General Clauses Act regarding the continuation of legal proceedings.
Reference to Articles 203-D, 203-F, and 203-H of the Constitution concerning repugnancy to Islamic injunctions.
Interpretation of Article 264 and its limitations due to Article 203-A.
Objectives Resolution under Article 2-A emphasizes establishment of Islamic society.
sections: Section 6 of the General Clauses Act
key_issues: Repugnancy of pre-emption law to Islamic injunctions.
Effectiveness of Supreme Court's judgment on pre-emption law.
Applicability of Article 264 to repealed laws.

maxims.Repugnancy Principle: A law repugnant to Islamic injunctions ceases to have effect upon the specified date.

legal_terms.Pre-emption: The right to purchase property before others.

words_and_phrases.If possible: Interpreted as 'reasonably possible in a business sense.'

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the dismissal of Muhammad Sharif's writ petition for pre-emption rights over disputed land. The court upheld the Supreme Court's decision declaring the law granting pre-emption rights to tenants repugnant to Islamic injunctions. The law ceased to have effect on 31-7-1986, rendering the petitioner's claim invalid.
key_points: Petitioner filed suit for possession of land through right of pre-emption.
Assistant Commissioner decreed the suit on 26-2-1983.
Appellate Authority overturned the decision on 24-6-1984, stating petitioner was a mortgagee, not a tenant.
Revision petition dismissed by Member, Board of Revenue on 31-10-1985.
Supreme Court judgment (P L D 1986 S C 360) declared law granting right of pre-emption to tenants repugnant to Islam.
Government failed to amend the law by the deadline of 31-7-1986, making the Supreme Court decision effective.
legal_analysis: Article 203-H allows continuation of proceedings until law is declared repugnant.
Article 264 does not apply as repeal is legislative, not judicial.
Article 203-A overrides Article 264 in cases of repugnancy to Islamic injunctions.
Objectives Resolution under Article 2-A emphasizes establishment of Islamic society.
final_reasoning: Petitioner sought enforcement of a law that ceased to have effect under Article 203-D(3)(b). Writ petition dismissed as law is no longer valid.
